mahabharatam.title: Sri Mahabharatam
mahabharatam.description: Dive into the timeless wisdom, divine pastimes, and the great war of Kurukshetra. Explore the 18 Parvas that define Dharma.
mahabharatam.introText: The Mahabharata is organized into eighteen books, known as Parvas. Each book unfolds a crucial phase of the great epic, from the origins of the Kuru dynasty to the final ascent to heaven. Select a Parva below to begin your journey.

p01.title: Adi Parva
p01.subtitle: Book of the Beginning
p01.description: The origins of the Kuru lineage, the birth of the Pandavas and Kauravas, and the growing animosity between the cousins leading to the burning of the lac house.

p02.title: Sabha Parva
p02.subtitle: Book of the Assembly Hall
p02.description: The establishment of Indraprastha, the fateful game of dice, and the exile of the Pandavas into the forest for thirteen years.

p03.title: Vana Parva
p03.subtitle: Book of the Forest
p03.description: Also known as Aranya Parva. The twelve years of exile in the forest, featuring many sub-stories including Nala and Damayanti, and Savitri and Satyavan.

p04.title: Virata Parva
p04.subtitle: Book of Virata
p04.description: The thirteenth year of exile spent in disguise at the court of King Virata. The Pandavas successfully remain undetected.

p05.title: Udyoga Parva
p05.subtitle: Book of Effort
p05.description: The period of preparation for war. Peace negotiations fail despite Lord Krishna's mission to the Kaurava court.

p06.title: Bhishma Parva
p06.subtitle: Book of Bhishma
p06.description: The first ten days of the great war. Contains the divine **Bhagavad Gita** spoken by Lord Krishna to Arjuna. Bhishma falls on a bed of arrows.

p07.title: Drona Parva
p07.subtitle: Book of Drona
p07.description: Dronacharya commands the Kaurava army. This parva details the brutal war, the death of Abhimanyu, and the fall of Drona.

p08.title: Karna Parva
p08.subtitle: Book of Karna
p08.description: Karna leads the Kaurava army for two days. The intense rivalry between Karna and Arjuna concludes with Karna's death.

p09.title: Shalya Parva
p09.subtitle: Book of Shalya
p09.description: The final day of the war. Shalya commands and falls. Duryodhana is defeated by Bhima in a mace duel.

p10.title: Sauptika Parva
p10.subtitle: Book of Sleeping Warriors
p10.description: Ashwatthama, Kripa, and Kritavarma attack the sleeping Pandava army at night, killing the sons of the Pandavas.

p11.title: Stri Parva
p11.subtitle: Book of the Women
p11.description: The women of the Kuru and Pandava households lament the death of their husbands, sons, and kinsmen on the battlefield.

p12.title: Shanti Parva
p12.subtitle: Book of Peace
p12.description: The longest book. Bhishma, lying on his arrow bed, instructs Yudhishthira on the duties of a king, philosophy, and liberation (Moksha).

p13.title: Anushasana Parva
p13.subtitle: Book of Instructions
p13.description: Final instructions from Bhishma. Contains the **Vishnu Sahasranama** (Thousand Names of Vishnu). Bhishma leaves his mortal body.

p14.title: Ashvamedhika Parva
p14.subtitle: Book of the Horse Sacrifice
p14.description: Yudhishthira performs the Ashvamedha Yajna (Horse Sacrifice) to establish supremacy and atone for the war's sins.

p15.title: Ashramavasika Parva
p15.subtitle: Book of the Hermitage
p15.description: Dhritarashtra, Gandhari, and Kunti leave the palace for the forest (Vanaprastha ashram) and eventually perish in a forest fire.

p16.title: Mausala Parva
p16.subtitle: Book of the Clubs
p16.description: The fratricidal destruction of the Yadava clan through iron clubs. Lord Krishna ends his incarnation and returns to his abode.

p17.title: Mahaprasthanika Parva
p17.subtitle: Book of the Great Journey
p17.description: The Pandavas renounce their kingdom and begin their final journey towards the Himalayas. Only Yudhishthira reaches the summit with a dog.

p18.title: Svargarohana Parva
p18.subtitle: Book of the Ascent to Heaven
p18.description: Yudhishthira enters heaven. He sees the Kauravas there and his brothers in hell (an illusion/test). Finally, all attain their spiritual abodes.
